H0.text: Earth rotates on its axis is the reason the Northern Hemisphere receives more daylight than the Southern Hemisphere on June 21st, when the summer solstice causes the northern part of the Earth to receive longer hours of sunlight.

H1.text: Earth is tilted on its axis, which causes the Northern Hemisphere to receive more daylight than the Southern Hemisphere on June 21st, the day that has the most hours of sunlight in the North and the fewest in the South.

H2.text: The Sun moves closer to the Northern Hemisphere explains why June 21st has more hours of sunlight in the Northern Hemisphere than in the Southern Hemisphere.

H3.text: The Sun releases more energy to the Northern Hemisphere on June 21st, which explains why the Northern Hemisphere receives more daylight than the Southern Hemisphere on the same day.

A4.text: Earth's axis remains tilted in the same direction with reference to the background stars throughout a year – this is known as axial parallelism. This means that one pole (and the associated hemisphere of Earth) will be directed away from the Sun at one side of the orbit, and half an orbit later (half a year later) this pole will be directed towards the Sun.

A5.text: This is the cause of Earth's seasons.
